job_title: Diversity and Inclusion in Wilkes Barre, PA
pros: Friendly, helping hand, family for life
cons: White-centric but has people who care

review_title: Okay for a short stay to augment a resume, but no future available here if you're a professional administrator.
pros: People are very friendly if you're white and lead a fairly conventional life. Students are down to earth and mostly middle- or working-class so they sincerely appreciate the guidance and experience you provide. Benefits are great and the university's GO program may even afford you the opportunity to open the world to a great of students in a very impactful way through travel. You can gain a broad range of experiences in different fields. And when you find an administrator who knows what they're doing,  there is ample opportunity for mentorship.
cons: Protect yourself - SU has no qualms about taking advantage of their employees in terms of asking you to sacrifice your personal life or work for pay lower than industry standards. And Human Resources is the most user-unfriendly office on campus so there is no one go go to for help. Administrators who know what they are doing usually leave quickly because they can - incompetent directors stay for decades and clog the system,  serving as road blocks to any real progress. Working here is a bit like spinning your wheels.

pros: Flexible Scheduling, Decent Pay, Easy
cons: Problematic Management, Boring at times

job_title: Student Affairs Professional in Selinsgrove, PA
pros: Small atmosphere where you can know all of your colleagues. The community is safe and overall very friendly. I was lucky to have a very good salary and a very flexible work schedule. I found that most departments were willing to collaborate and help each other out.
cons:
I found that some of the administration had their own agendas and would treat others fairly who expressed opposing viewpoints. There seemed to be a "Mean Girls" effect going on where there were some people in Student Life who were part of the "in group," who took care of each other. Meanwhile there was an "out group" that did not get the same access to resources and were eventually pushed out of the university. Employee morale is now low due to the cutting of benefits and pay freezes. 
There wasn't much room to advance in your career because the institution was so small and positions were rarely vacant.

pros:
--President Lemons is a top-notch leader who believes in his employees' qualifications, gives us the leeway to expand our programs, but is still happy to become involved.
--The insurance benefits are great, with people making the least paying in the least and people making the most paying in the most. 
--People tend to stay with the university for a long time, so your community is very tight-knit and people try hard to take care of one another.
--Many employees of different positions qualify to take free classes, and certain workers' children qualify for tuition exchange after working with the university for a certain period of time.
cons:
There are very few cons that I can think of... but if I must, then...
--I think that there is still an old boys club in the athletics department.
--The university is in a very rural area, so people who crave a lot of culture may not like the location much.

review_title: Not concerned with keeping good staff
pros: The staff is talented, kind and genuine. Students are a pleasure to work with. The campus is beautiful. Time off and 401k matching are generous.
cons: Staff are overworked and underpaid, meaning the best always leave and there is constant turnover. Poor managers are allowed to remain in charge while their entire staff quits in frustration and no one does a thing. HR policies are applied unevenly throughout the university; for example, one office is allowed to dress casually and enjoy flexible telework options while another just down the hall is expected to dress like they work on Wall Street and maintain rigid office hours. Approach to telework is significantly behind the times, which is detrimental to a workplace in such an isolated location.

job_title: Part-time Campus Center Secretary in Selinsgrove, PA
pros: I worked mornings, which suited my schedule.  I worked with a variety of students, which was very interesting.  I worked with several full-time employees, and I learned a lot during my time there.
cons: It was only part-time so there were no benefits.  One of the jobs that I had was getting the caps and gowns ready for graduation, which involved going into a basement storage area, which was a bit creepy.

pros:
Amazing campus with a sincerely unique student environment. 
Feels as though you are given the responsibilities of a full-time manager, and you will learn a lot if you apply yourself in and outside the classroom.
cons: There is a lot of responsibility in moral discussions and you must work to make sure your voice is heard and that you take on leadership roles. There are lot to go around and it is easy to find but it will take work and you will have to manage a tough schedule if you get involved.

review_title: Very rewarding to work with grateful and capable students
pros:
Susquehanna is a wonderful place to teach, do research, and feel like an important part of the students' lives and the institution's history.  The senior staff are very personable and know every employee by name. The student body is economically diverse (96% on financial aid and a third on Pell Grants) and very grateful for the chance to receive a personalized education. Faculty mentor students and perform advising, so there is the opportunity for a high touch experience for both faculty and students. Faculty have many opportunities for professional development and training.
The support staff is largely terrific and also devoted to student development and education. Athletics respects the academic mission, and most faculty respect the important role of athletics in the development of student well-being. There are many opportunities to enjoy the fine arts, free tickets to shows, free use of the pool and fitness center, free and close parking, and private offices. Faculty self-governance works, and there are many opportunities for meaningful service. 
Starbucks and banking services are on campus. Real estate nearby is relatively cheap, the schools are new and good, and the town has good recreation and free garden plots.
Due to prudent fiscal planning, the university is in good financial shape. There is no deferred maintainance, and the buildings and grounds look great. The endowment isn't like Harvard's but is better than most of the competitors and still growing. The school is 160 years old and looks like it plans to be here another 160.
cons: The university is "centrally isolated," meaning it is 3 hours from Philly, Washington, and NYC. This may be why it's not better known. While most of the national shopping and eating chains are nearby, there are few choices for authentic ethnic cuisine. Diversity in the area has improved in my 14 years here, but this could be better.

pros: Susquehanna University is a fun place to work. It is a place where there is a lot happening. I enjoyed meeting people from all over. The work was varied.
cons: Although they offered great benefits, the pay was lacking. Unless you are faculty, don't expect to get paid much. Staff is considered an expense and your pay will reflect that.

review_title: Good work environment with easy access to information and individual performance.
pros: Provided me with personal communication skills that I will be able to use for the rest of my life as well as the ability to manage my time around work.
cons: I was unable to work the desired hours a week that would provide me with enough compensation to be able to fulfill my monetary needs.

review_title: Fun work atmosphere, but school thinks it's better than it is
pros: Great place to work. Relaxed atmosphere
cons: many staff/students think entirely too highly of themselves and the school. Average academics, but they pretend to be comparable to Bucknell or Gettysburg...not the case.
